security: Revealing details of security checks on individuals and organizations, as well as operational assignments and potential false claims related to CIA employment, could compromise security protocols and ongoing investigations. For example, 'Office of Security records reflect that an individual, probably identical to Steve Van Cleave of Atlanta, Georgia, had falsely claimed to the State Department in January 1974 that he worked for CIA in Latin America under cover of Coca Cola Company.' This information, if disseminated, could prompt similar fraudulent claims or obstruct future investigations.
summary: A memorandum from the CIA's Security Support Division to F. I. G. Coleman regarding an FBI investigation into alleged CIA activities, detailing the results of security record searches for specific individuals and organizations.
summary_one_paragraph: This memorandum, dated August 21, 1974, from Charles S. Phalen, Chief of the Security Support Division, to F. I. G. Coleman, C/OPS/LSN, concerns an FBI investigation of alleged CIA activities and reports on the results of security record searches. The memo indicates no prior information on Security Defense System, Intelligence Services, Ltd., Advance Security Corporation, or Howard Gibson, but provides information on Mitchell Livingston Werbell III, noting his past OSS service and reputation as a 'wheeler dealer.' It also recounts details previously shared with FBI Liaison Frank Schwartz regarding John Patrick Muldoonâ€™s Agency career and potential employment with Security Consultants International, as well as information about Steve Van Cleave's false claims of CIA employment.
title: FBI Investigation of Allegations Regarding CIA Activities
sender: Charles S. Phalen, Chief, Security Support Division
